title: Dynamic Insights of Developing Functional Nanomaterials for Clean Energy and Microelectronics
content: In situ microscopy techniques provide arguably the most efficient methods for studying materials response to external stimuli at the nanometer scale for a vast range of materials and biological fields, and necessary to meet the immense societal demands for increasing technical capabilities especially for clean energy and microelectronic devices. During this talk, I will present two examples of in situ electron microscopy investigations aimed to accelerate new materials discovery in these fields, specifically, for clean energy, lithium ion batteries, and microelectronics, neuromorphic electronics.
